34.text:
We're after deer with a cat, we're in a barn
with Team Wild TV looking for feral pigeons.

42.text:
First we have got a problem with urban foxes.
It's late afternoon in a garden in south London

50.text:
and there is a little experiment being carried
out. The hypothesis under test is are urban

58.text:
foxes bold enough to take a baby sized object
out of its pram and the sound of a baby crying

63.text:
is so similar to a fox's natural prey it makes
the dummy prey even more attractive. The gentleman

71.text:
who filmed these events is a professional
pest controller and Fieldsports Channel viewer.

76.text:
He has seen the urban fox evolve into an opportunist
and just wants to see how conditioned they

82.text:
have become. Yes, the piglet will smell although
it was frozen, however, the buggy is covered

89.text:
in human scent and the babygrow is brand new.
The crying of the baby is a fascinating addition

95.text:
to this experiment. Here is a rabbit distress
call used by fox shooters all over the world

101.text:
to call in their quarry. Doesn't sound that
different to a baby does it? Robert Bucknell

111.text:
a foxing expert interviewed for our foxing
DVD says how closely these sounds resemble

118.text:
We might have loads of foxes which aren't
any trouble, but there are always one or two

121.text:
who will push the boundaries back. Hear something
wailing like a hare in distress and it goes

128.text:
and has a look and finds a nice piece of protein
there and have a nibble on it and therein

133.text:
lies the problem. There is always people getting
bitten and that sort of thing, it's pretty

139.text:
rare, but now it has become more news worthy
and we see it in the papers a little more.

144.text:
We are releasing this film not to demonise
foxes just to show that they are not pets.

150.text:
And organisations like the BBC should know
better. Here is their last months edition

156.text:
of Wild Life magazine and their step by step
guide to attracting foxes into your garden.

163.text:
Please don't have nightmares but make sure
your pet rabbits and guinea pigs are locked

172.text:
Urban foxes making news there, also making
news its David on the Fieldsports Channel

184.text:
A new study suggests that dogs have been man's
best friend for at least 30,000 years. A pair

193.text:
of dog skulls uncovered in digs in Siberia
and Belgium have been aged at 33,000 years

198.text:
old. It shows dogs were domesticated long
before any other animal, including sheep,

203.text:
cows or goats. The skulls had shorter snouts
and wider jaws than wild animals, such as

208.text:
wolves. It suggests dogs were used for companionship
and protection.

213.text:
Two men have been injured in shooting accidents
during game shoots in North Yorkshire, prompting

218.text:
police to issue a gun safety warning. One
was struck in the face by pellets during a

223.text:
pheasant shoot in Strensall, near York. A
day later, another was hit in the leg on farmland

228.text:
near Selby. Both men suffered only minor injuries.
Police said accidents were rare but warned

234.text:
shooters to keep safety in mind. North Yorkshire
Police said it had seized the guns involved

239.text:
while officers investigated the exact circumstances
of the incidents

244.text:
.
And finally in the week a bluefin tuna sold

247.text:
at auction in Japan for nearly half a million
pounds, prompting fear that this fish is becoming

252.text:
rarer, a US angler has caught what might be
a world record yellowfin tuna, the blue fin's

258.text:
smaller cousin. It's a 90x62 inch yellowfin
estimated at 432.4 pounds. The current 405-pound

271.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
news. Stalking the stories fishing for facts.

282.text:
Thank you David. Weather looks better there
than here.

287.text:
Now Roy Lupton is out stalking fallow does
he's calling in foxes in daylight and he even

293.text: has a problem with a dog walker.

296.text:
In fieldsports channel towers Roy is known
as "the postman",.. he always delivers - this

303.text:
morning he hasn't got a little red van but
a six wheel beast which has been defying physics

308.text:
in the highlands of scotland as he hunts blue
hares with his eagles.

311.text:
He's on his round on his ground in Sussex.
He has a little flash around for some foxes

316.text: but the first stop is going to be fallow does.

319.text:
I've not done any doe culling for quite a
while so I've been away in Scotland flying

326.text:
the birds so really have got to get cracked
on with the doe cull because it is getting

331.text:
on in the season so hopefully we can catch
up with a few this morning. We have got Dom

335.text:
with us this morning so we've got a second
gun, so what we are going to do is try and

340.text:
position Dom in some of the places as we stalk
through if any deer break through then Dom

345.text:
will have a chance for a shot or two as they
come through from the spinneys, so fingers

351.text: crossed we will give it a go.

354.text:
Although he's on parkland - the fences are
no more and the herds here are transient.

359.text:
He'd like to take about five out of the local
population.

362.text:
The only problem we have got this morning
is where we are going into is very difficult

368.text:
to get into by foot you've got to go across
a stream so the distraction to the deer if

373.text:
we do get one is always a problem, so that's
why we have brought the argo this morning,

377.text:
so if we do get a few then we will have the
means of getting them out.

382.text:
Dom is here as well - which could be interesting
- If Roy is "the postman" Dom is postman pat.

389.text:
You are going to be filming with Roy so which
one of us is the jinx? It will be an interesting

397.text:
scientific experiment to find out whether
you are the reason or I am the reason we never

402.text: get anything. My money is on you.

407.text:
Roy has a good idea where the deer will be
and positions Dom to cover the exit point

414.text:
As hoped the deer are in a spinney across
the bridge but they don't hang about. We crawl

419.text:
across the broken bridge - Roy lighting the
way with his cheeks.

431.text:
The plan has worked in reverse and Dom has
pushed 2 does our way - Roy shoots and for

437.text: a change the young doe runs...

440.text: The group we initially spotted takes flight.

443.text:
Time to do some fieldwork and follow the blood
trail. We find the doe under a fallen branch..

447.text:
You normally find a good constant trail so
where we are here we've got a fantastic out

452.text:
shot a lot of blood where she stood for a
while and then she has run. On fallow you

457.text:
can lose the blood quite easily as they move
around the muscle can cover up the exit wound

465.text:
and then you can lose the blood as it pulls
into their chest cavity, but as I said she

470.text: is not going to be far.

477.text: We find the doe under a fallen branch.

480.text:
She's just laying down there so you can see
that if we hadn't followed the blood we would

485.text:
have really struggled to find her so especially
the way she has laid if they have laid and

490.text:
their white under belly is showing towards
you the same as when you are rabbit shooting

493.text:
at night they are easy to find, but if they
are laid the other way from you like she is

497.text:
there just tucked in it's incredibly difficult
to see them sometimes.

502.text:
There we go, absolutely nothing wrong with
the shot there it was obviously just when

509.text:
her adrenaline was up where she had been spooked
by Dom and came onto the bank there. She just

516.text:
had enough to stand there and then tottered
away down here not more than 50 yards, but

521.text:
when you've got the cover like the bracken
and fallen trees it can be very difficult

525.text:
to find them, they can be right under your
nose but you still can't see them. Again it's

528.text:
always a good idea if you have got one to
bring a dog with you even with perfect shots

533.text:
because it can take you a long time to find
the carcasses in conditions like this if you

540.text: Dom joins us - and looks a bit sheepish..

547.text: I don't want to talk about it.

551.text:
Dom takes the strain and get to grips with
the young doe.

555.text:
Roy is keen for another so we head off to
a different part of the estate. We spot deer

564.text:
immediately but they're not on our ground
- another 50 yards and for a change the deer

589.text:
The camera remains standing but Roy and Dom
hit the deck - 3 animals are just yards away

595.text:
in what appears to be a great shooting position
but all the boys can see are rear ends.

605.text:
We follow up slowly - and still they remain
tricky to nail down... then they evaporate

611.text:
and we soon find out why - a dog walker in
woodland with no footpaths - Roy is firm but

620.text:
Hello, hi there please could you refrain from
walking your dog through here, it is not a

622.text:
foot path and it's very dangerous as there
is a lot stalking activity goes on in here.

631.text:
This isn't a footpath here at all, so it's
incredibly dangerous to walk through these

634.text:
parts of the woods, because there is a lot
of shooting going on.

641.text:
The other thing is could you keep the dogs
on leads because we have had a lot deer killed

648.text:
What they do is run them against fences and
then kill them against the fences even stressing

654.text:
them because they are pregnant now, so if
they get chased about a lot it damages them.

659.text:
Although she said her dog wouldn't kill deer
that dog was perfectly capable of chasing

664.text:
the deer and running them up against the fences
and causing damage. Obviously as the season

669.text:
progresses, the does are pregnant at the moment,
another month or two and they are going to

675.text:
be very heavily pregnant and if they start
to get chased around like that it's going

679.text:
to cause a lot of damage to the future generations
of deer what we've got in here, so yeah, you

684.text:
feel you are banging your head against a brick
wall sometimes, so you have just got to try

689.text:
and put your point across and hope that eventually
it sinks in.

693.text:
With our stalk spoiled and it's such a glorious
morning Roy feels it's just right for a squeek.

699.text:
He lets rip with the silva fox - 8 minutes
later and bang we have a very close observer.

716.text:
I heard you whispering the other side of the
tree which was blocking my view and then when

728.text:
he ran in he stopped obviously Roy trying
to get him to stop on the call and yes, a

735.text: lot closer than I was expecting.

736.text:
That fox just appeared to my right hand side
here, he came up behind us and made us, I

741.text:
didn't want to move until we got the camera
on it and I was hoping he'd move off and we

747.text:
would get a chance to squeeze the trigger
and Dom did a super job as the fox just crossed

752.text:
our line down the bottom here, I was trying
to stop him but he was just moseying through,

756.text:
he had slowed down a bit, but as this one
appeared and the shot went off there was another

761.text:
fox coming up from the bottom, just making
its way through the thick bramble there so

767.text:
obviously with that report going off it's
unlikely he would have come anyway. That was

773.text:
a fantastic call he really came in close on
that one. So it looks good.

780.text:
Time to recover that deer with the Argo - to
increase the stakes it's going to be a water

787.text:
I've got to do me bungs up to get back across
the river.

796.text: Why don't we use the bridge Roy?

803.text:
A successful and eventful morning - and even
though there are bridges everywhere Roy and

810.text: Dom seem to enjoy making the most of it.

813.text:
If you'd like to find out more about the argocat
go to www.argocat.com

822.text:
From deer to doves where Nottinghamshire farmers
have a problem with feral pigeons pinching

828.text: all their feed they call in Team Wild TV.

838.text:
Whether stalking antelope on the African plains,
foxes in the fields of southern England, or

844.text:
this - feral pigeons in a farmer's barn in
Staffordshire - you have to approach your

848.text: quarry carefully and with plenty of forethought.

852.text:
You can tell this is the perfect environment
for feral pigeons, there's a grain store with

868.text:
plenty of feed in here the rafters provide
great places to roost you can see by the floor

874.text:
there is plenty of scat, these guys live in
here full time. We're just going to make our

879.text:
way round the barn just nice and steady using
all these bags and machinery as cover using

883.text:
these Zeiss range finding binos, because it
is a big shed and we do need to make sure

888.text:
we are checking our ranges. The rifle is zero'd
to 15 yards and 35 yards it probably shoots

893.text:
at about an inch high at 20 but any further
than that at 40 or 50 it's a couple of inches

899.text:
difference and we don't want to be causing
any damage to the asbestos or the wooden framework

902.text:
here. So we are going to make our way around
and see what we can find.

905.text:
See those two up there on the rafter, on the
beam, I'm going to take the one on the left,

913.text: you take the one on the right ,on three.

918.text:
Is that one, two, three or is that one, two,
three [shoot]?

940.text:
This is a livestock feed protection exercise.
Once we have planned our approach, the shooting

947.text:
There's two more up there, reload. I'll take
the left, you take the right.

973.text:
I've been lucky so far, these guys, these
pigeons haven't been shot for a while. The

985.text:
good thing is that these air rifles these
days are very quiet, mine has got a silencer

990.text:
on with a carbine barrel and Keith has just
got a Schreider. So we've just taken a few

996.text:
shots we missed a couple, they don't seem
overly concerned they're flying out, just

1000.text:
flying round a couple of times and coming
back, so if we just hold fire for a little

1003.text: bit we should get more shots.

1014.text:
So pretty good day so far. That's eight in
the bag, so what we are going to do now, I

1019.text:
think we've pretty much shot this out, so
why don't we head back to Fonty's place and

1024.text: see if we can get some more in the sheds.

1025.text: See if we can get some more in there.

1030.text:
You need the farmer on your side. And you
need the farmer to know that you're on his

1035.text:
The reason we've called you in is because
the pigeons are destroying the crops, causing

1042.text:
messes in the barns which slows up growth
stages, but you boys have come in to control

1047.text:
the numbers so we are not going to have this
damage in the future.

1050.text: What sort of mess to they cause in the barns?

1053.text:
In the sheds muck all over the machinery which
burns the paint and that sort of thing, it

1058.text:
also keeps them out of the crop stores, food
stores, they'll get through every available

1064.text:
gap and they will cause defecating within
the food stores which you don't want.

1072.text:
Back at the shooting, and the ferals are still
providing plenty of challenges.

1076.text:
Another pigeon just flew into the barn over
here and Keith hasn't had a brilliant day's

1081.text:
shooting, he's not up to his usual high standard
so there's been a bit of an argument over

1083.text:
who's going to take the shot because I like
to make sure the bird goes into the bag, but

1087.text:
Killer is pretty confident he can get it,
so it's down to you now Killer.

1094.text:
Actually there are two birds in here so what
we are going to do is on three we are going

1107.text: Mr H one, Mr Killer zero.

1119.text:
I reckon that was Ian's shooting. Come on
pick it up, pick it up. Bring it on, good

1141.text: So look at the mastery man over beast.

1144.text:
Come on you, here. Here bring it on, bring
it on, good dog. Good dog, good dog.

1155.text: Are you having a few problems?

1159.text: Yeah, I'm going to have to go in.

1173.text:
As you can see Keith is a highly trained dog
handler. He is still trying to get that bird

1180.text:
from that soft mouthed spaniel over there.
This is not unusual if you have seen Keith

1185.text:
operating in the field, it's pretty much par
for the course. We can faintly hear the Benny

1189.text:
Hill's theme track playing in the background,
it's not going to get any better, we might

1194.text:
get the bird back in one piece, we have known
that before.

1205.text: That will be my glove then.

1211.text:
Enthusiastic little fellows as you can see
a perfect heart shot just above the chest

1220.text:
in the crop area and when you are shooting
pigeons inside it's always best to go for

1225.text:
something which has got a good size target
area. Obviously the best shot is a head or

1228.text:
a neck shot by the time you've got through
the feathers the neck is small, the head bobbing

1232.text:
around all the time you might not get a clean
shot and you might hit the building. Luckily

1236.text:
for me this dropped straight away, died straight
away and I have got all these helpful retrievers

1241.text: to help me pick my birds. So come on guys.

1247.text:
So we've had a great day and, because we knocked
down 12, Mark's really happy, the air range

1253.text:
has performed really perfectly. We'll go back
in a couple of weeks to make sure we stay

Well we are back next week and if you are
